author: oaklandmatt
content:
I always tailor it to the artist in some way. It's a combination of making fresh ideas specifically for them and taking existing ideas that could work (sometimes reworking existing ideas). I never go into a session like an actual blind date where I don't know anything about them.

The challenge is always do I make something that sounds like what they've done, or do I make something that sounds like where they're going? That's impossible to answer. I've had success in major label POP artist sessions by having a 100 year old piano and specifically not playing tracks. Meaning, you never know if an artist is tired of doing the same shit. Because I have confidence in my skill as a producer, I'm happy to get an A+ ballad because I know I can turn it into whatever production I want. "In The Name Of Love" is my most successful example of this. It's an emotional 3 chord piano ballad that was produced into a festival EDM anthem. 

I've had the most success being prepared for all options. Mostly because that makes me flexible for what an artist is feeling that day, but also because the more stuff I make, the more music I'm making. If I prep for a session, I'm not working cold. The prep is also like a psychological and creative warm up for me. Prep makes me a better improviser.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
the answer largely depends on how A&R driven the project is. sometimes the A&R is really running the show (like with a young pop boy band or something) and sometimes the A&R doesn't really matter and the artist is the whole identity. 

a VERY loose way i often think about it is like this: if you're going to lean toward the A&R, do it on the production, not the songwriting. every great song i've been a part of writing (and i mean literally 100% of them) have been about capturing an emotional moment or excitement that is happening in the room with the people in the room. if you start thinking about "what does the A&R want the lyrics to be like?" you're gonna lose that.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok this is one of my favorite topics ever.

Happy to go deeper, but the gist is this: I believe people connect to the underlying emotion, even if their analytical brain isn't reading or understand the lyrics. If the emotion is authentic, the song has a MUCH better chance of connecting. Without that emotion, it is almost impossible. 

The more I write songs, the older I get, the more I work with the greatest songwriters, the more I think that writing an authentic emotion is everything. 

A favorite example (I have 100 more, just ask): 

Party In The USA. Silly pop song? Or deep truth about the power of music being able to transcend loneliness? Go into the lyric and you realize it's Jessie J writing about her first time coming to Los Angeles: 

Stepped off the plane at LAX with a dream and a cardigan... am I gonna fit in... everybody looks so famous... I'm feeling homesick, too much pressure and I'm nervous... but then my favorite song comes on the radio... I know I'm gonna be ok... it's a party in the USA"

Tbh I tear up every time I think about this song. Yeah people might not analyze the lyric, but the reason this song will play for the next 50 years (and not the 1mil other simple songs about having a party) is the deep, authentic, universal emotion underlying the record.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You're absolutely right that trying to copy existing hits rarely makes great songs. He's 100% correct on that point.

I'm saying that songwriters often fall into the trap of trying to be "original." They mistakenly think this means they should try to invent new phrases or not use "generic" words or try to do something "interesting" with the chords. Instead of doing the only original thing that is possible which is tell your story and express your taste. This is actually much more difficult to do because it's incredibly vulnerable.

You can compose fully original compositions this way. But it's also interesting how much groundbreaking music comes from direct appropriation of existing popular music. 

From folk music ("Blowin In The Wind" is a melody from another song) to hip hop (all of sampling) to producers and DJs making careers from remixes, playing around with current or past hits can also yield incredible new music.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Quote time 

“Instead of saying, “I’m stuck, I can’t come up with anything good,” it’s far more effective to say, “I’ve finished this, and now I need to make it better.” Or possibly, “I finished this, and it can’t be made better, but now I’m ready to do the new thing, because look at all I’ve learned.” 

This is the story of every human innovation. 
This is the story of every good idea, every new project, every pop song, every novel. There was a bad idea. And then there was a better one. 

If you want to complain that you don’t have any good ideas, please show me all your bad ideas first. 

Befriending your bad ideas is a useful way forward. They’re not your enemy. They are essential steps on the path to better.”

Chap 167 of “The Practice” by Seth Godin.

I feel like this is very in line with getting better at all of the creative crafts out there! 

Sub in “Show me all your bad hooks” or “show me all your bad mixes” and you are headed in the right direction.

author: Brian Reynolds
content:
"The truth is you could slit my throat
And with my one last gasping breath
I'd apologize for bleeding on your shirt"
Taking Back Sunday

I still remember walking into Hot Topic and doing what I always did. Walked directly to the headphones, that had 6 CDs loaded up to choose from listening. Drawn immediately to the NJ Parkway signage and a sticker that said, "If you like Thursday and New Found Glory". Hit play and I was all in from second one. 

The lyrics and especially the one above I couldn't get enough of on this record. They are so visceral and clever. 

The imagery of having you neck slit is like horror and action movie territory. But here it is in an angsty punk rock song about lost love. 

Starting the line with "the truth is" somehow enhances the line slit my throat. Its great storytelling.

Then to top all the clever with the killer line of all killer lines. "I'd apologize for bleeding on your shirt." The painful self awareness that somehow thru it all, your devotion remains. Youre still deferential to your tormentor.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes x1000

Study the best things, even if they don't always seem to apply directly to what you're doing. 

Max Martin is maybe the best at making vocals sound A+. He is well known as a detail oriented, vocal-focused pop savant. He is often a part of every choice from writing lyrics and melody all the way to adjusting sibilance in the mix. His instincts for great melody and rhythm, paired with lyrics that sound good, is unmatched. And I say "sound good," because though I think many of the lyrics of his songs are meaningful (especially with the best lyric co-writers), the choice of words and how they are emphasized and enunciated is what separates him from everyone else. It's like Michael Jackson. 

Do some YouTube searching on artists talking about working with Max Martin. You can learn a LOT about writing vocal from him.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Hmm, probably the likes of @BatMeckley and co could speak to this too, but the social skills ain't always the thing.

I've been in rooms with shy/quieter people who are just incredible at what they do. In one case, on a very high profile session, one of the beatmakers literally didn't speak to anyone, ever. He was 19 at the time, literally only opened his mouth to very politely ask me for my email address so he could fly the beat into Pro Tools to cut vocals. But he was making absolute fire, and even though he didn't speak, you could feel a good vibe off him.

I've also been in rooms with *unbelievably* obnoxious characters (the occasional particularly unpleasant example of that LA type we were discussing recently). Utterly repugnant as people, but their work is undeniable.

I know who I prefer to be in a room with (and that really does count for a lot, in my experience), but in the speed dating world of pop music writing that a lot of people go through, you get all sorts. 

Not everyone is super charismatic of course, but that's just the world. Either way, 90% of the people I've met at the highest level are really delightful.

Also, my experience has been that the more accomplished the artist/writer/producer, the more lovely they've been. They've got nothing to prove, and perhaps at a certain level, anyone who's not truly undeniable has already been filtered out of those rooms by being a jerk on the way there.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think that is what I am after; How do you say the same idea or concept/story but deliver it tastefully. Just like the same E major chord could be delivered in different voicings and different style of playing or instruments even. 

Maybe it’s just about paying attention to it more. I generally pay more attention to music than words by default, so that might be a factor that plays into it. 

Technically- with drums for example, you can use the same tools, try to play it or sequence it with the feel as close to it as possible, and break down what’s on it in terms of processing. If I go further, I can look at how the drums are interacting with the rest of the ensemble. If I just want to rip off the drums from a song, the first three will pretty much get me there. 

D’Angelo’s Voodoo is an album I constantly go back to study for the band interaction. Questlove is usually playing straight eighth notes, and very simple pattern. but how open the hihat is, and where he’s hitting, and when he makes the choices to pop the hihat out or kind of let it hide behind the instrumentation is very interesting. Perhaps subtle spontaneous decisions like that isn’t really replicable but I just take it in physically and try to see why he made this by looking at what other instruments are doing. You can just pay attention to how he plays hi hat and go wild playing just the hat along

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Do the songwriters get paid to create those demos?  No...  but they often PAY OTHERS to help them make the demo possible.  Nashville folk will often have "Demo Days" where a group of Ace players charge a flat fee to perform and record the rhythm section (for instance, could be anything the song needs). They might record 5-10 tracks in a day. I'm sure some have done more. These "demo day tracks" are used by songwriters to then pitch their track to recording artists, labels, anyone.  There's also a whole army of producers ready to help songwriters demo-up...  where the songwriter pays a producer to turnkey the track.  Sometimes it's one guy playing everything or a few remote players all chipping in under the producers direction.  

And...  these are viewed as a "very basic demo" in the eyes of industry vets. A really good "one take" by great players with high quality equipment recording the basic tracks is a strong demo but not fully produced. Happens all the time, but the producer (and their team) gets paid by the songwriter (or their team) to produce the track.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: American Hip Hop and Pop are much more "single producer" centric too.  Even then...  there's often a team of people behind the curtain.  I know a gospel keyboard player that does A LOT of top-line ghost writing for big names in Hip Hop.  On the surface it LOOKS like a single producer, but there's a group of people helping behind the scenes.
